{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Use British English|date=November 2014}} {{coord|51|30|47.7|N|0|5|21.7|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} {{Infobox building | name = Mansion House | image = Mansion House London.jpg | caption = | location_town = [[London]], [[EC postcode area|EC4]] | location_country = United Kingdom | coordinates = | architect = [[George Dance the Elder]] | embedded = | map_type = | map_caption = | client = |current_tenants = [[Lord Mayor of London]] | logo = | website = [https://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/about-the-city/mansion-house/Pages/default.aspx Mansion House] | engineer = | construction_start_date=1739 | date_demolished = | style = [[Palladian architecture|Palladian]] }} '''Mansion House''' is the [[official residence]] of the [[Lord Mayor of London]]. It is a Grade I [[listed building]].{{NHLE|num=1064604|desc=|accessdate=28 September 2015}} It is used for some of the [[City of London]]'s [[official functions]], including two annual [[white tie]] dinners. At the Easter banquet, the main speaker is the [[Foreign Secretary]], who then receives a reply from the [[Dean of the Diplomatic Corps]], i.e. the longest-serving ambassador. In early June, it is the turn of the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] to give his "Mansion House Speech" about the state of the British economy. ==History== [[File:Mansion House J.Woods after a picture by Hablot Browne & R.Garland publ 1837 edited.jpg|thumb|An 1837 view showing one of the two high attics. They were nicknamed the "Mayor's Nest" and "Noah's Ark".]] [[File:Egyptian Hall Mansion House edited.jpg|thumb|An early 19th century banquet in the Egyptian Hall at the Mansion House]] [[File:Mansion House-Public Session.jpg|thumb|A public session at the Mansion House, circa 1840]] Mansion House was built between 1739 and 1752, in the then fashionable [[Palladian architecture|Palladian style]] by the [[Surveyor (surveying)|surveyor]] and [[architect]] [[George Dance the Elder]]. The site, at the east end of [[Poultry, London|Poultry]], had previously been occupied by the [[Stocks Market]], which by the time of its closure was mostly used for the sale of herbs.{{cite book |last1= Britton|first1=John |last2=Pugin |first2=A.|chapter=An Account of the Mansion House|title=Illustrations of the Public Buildings of London: With Historical and Descriptive Accounts of each Edifice |url= |accessdate= |volume= 2|year=1828 |publisher= |location=London |pages=120–6}} The construction was prompted by a wish to put an end to the inconvenient practice of lodging the Lord Mayor in one of the City Halls. Dance won a competition over designs solicited from [[James Gibbs]] and [[Giacomo Leoni]], and uninvited submissions by [[Batty Langley]] and [[Isaac Ware]].{{cite book |last1=Summerson |first1=John |title= Georgian London|year=1962|publisher=Penguin Books |location= Harmondsworth |pages=61–2 }} Construction was slowed by the discovery of springs on the site, which meant piles had to be sunk to form the foundations. The original building had two clerestory roof extensions, nicknamed the "Mayor's Nest" (a pun on "mare's nest") and "Noah's Ark". In 1795 [[George Dance the Younger]] re-roofed the central courtyard, and had the "Noah's Ark" demolished. In the same year, the original grand staircase was removed to make way for a further two rooms. In 1835 the entrance steps were reduced to one flight, and in 1842 the "Mayor's Nest" was demolished after the [[ballroom]] was reconstructed. The Lord Mayor's private entrance in Walbrook was created in 1845, and in 1849 the former Swordbearer's Room was converted into the Justice Room, effectively the [[Magistrates' Court]] of the City, until 1999 when the court removed to a building on the opposite side of Walbrook.{{cite book|editors=Weinreb, Christopher, and Hibbert, Ben|title=The London Encyclopaedia|year=1992|publisher=Macmillan|page=509}} ==Funding== Mansion House was paid for in an unusual way: the City authorities, all [[Church of England]] men, found a way to tax those of other Christian denominations, particularly the [[Rational Dissenters]]. A [[British Unitarian|Unitarian]] named [[Samuel Sharpe]], banker by day and amateur Egyptologist by night, wrote about it in the 1830s, striking a blow against the [[Test Act|Test and Corporate Acts]]. The article was republished in 1872. Sharpe argues that Mansion House "remains as a monument of the unjust manner in which Dissenters were treated in the last century" (i.e. the 18th, in contrast to his own 19th, century).{{cite book|last1=Clayden|first1=PW|title=Samuel Sharpe|page=51|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924026852180/cu31924026852180_djvu.txt|accessdate=7 May 2016}} [[William Edward Hartpole Lecky]] in his ''History of England during the Eighteenth Century'' (1878) describes the funding of the construction of Mansion House as "a very scandalous form of persecution". There are over one hundred [[livery company|livery companies]], the senior members of which form a special electorate known as [[City_of_London_Corporation#Ceremonies_and_traditions|Common Hall]]. In 1748 the [[City of London Corporation]] devised a [[Catch-22]] situation to raise money, passing a by-law levying a heavy fine on any man who refused to stand for election, or who, once elected to office, refused to serve. In order to serve as a [[Sheriffs of the City of London|Sheriff of the City of London]], the individual had to have "taken [[Eucharist|the sacrament]] according to the [[Anglicanism#Eucharistic_discipline|Anglican rite]]" within the past year. This was exactly what [[English Dissenters]] could not, in conscience, do. "It would appear almost incredible, if the facts were not widely attested, that under these circumstances the City of London systematically elected wealthy Dissenters to the office in order that they should be objected to and fined, and that in this manner it extorted no less than £15,000. The electors appointed these Dissenters with a clear knowledge that they would not serve, and with the sole purpose of extorting money. One of those whom they selected was blind; another was bedridden." Some tried to appeal, but the process was immensely risky and costly, with the City holding all the cards. Eventually a man named Evans began a challenge which lasted ten years; in 1767, the House of Lords, drawing on the [[Toleration Act 1688]], agreed with [[William Murray, 1st Earl of Mansfield|Lord Mansfield]] and ruled to curtail the City's abuse of power.{{cite book|title=A History of England in the Eighteenth Century|date=1890|page=496-497|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyenglandei03leck#page/496/mode/2up|accessdate=7 May 2016}} (See ''Harrison'' v. ''Evans'' (1767), [http://www.commonlii.org/uk/cases/EngR/1767/33.pdf 3 Bro. Parl. Cas. 465].) In order to avoid [[civil disabilities]] such as this financially ruinous persecution, some Dissenters were known to take Communion in their [[parish church]] once a year; in the phraseology of the time, "occasional conformity". [[Thomas Abney]] rose to be Lord Mayor in this fashion.{{cite web|title=ABNEY, Sir Thomas (1640-1722), of Stoke Newington, Mdx. and Theobalds, Herts.|url=http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1690-1715/member/abney-sir-thomas-1640-1722|website=History of Parliament Online|publisher=Published in The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1690-1715, ed. D. Hayton, E. Cruickshanks, S. Handley, 2002|accessdate=7 May 2016}} The American author [[Mark Twain]] recounts the story in his own inimitable style in ''[[A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court]]'' (1889):
It reminded me of something I had read in my youth about the ingenious way in which the aldermen of London raised the money that built the Mansion House. A person who had not taken the Sacrament according to the Anglican rite could not stand as a candidate for sheriff of London. Thus Dissenters were ineligible; they could not run if asked, they could not serve if elected. The aldermen, who without any question were Yankees in disguise, hit upon this neat device: they passed a by-law imposing a fine of £400 upon any one who should refuse to be a candidate for sheriff, and a fine of £600 upon any person who, after being elected sheriff, refused to serve. Then they went to work and elected a lot of Dissenters, one after another, and kept it up until they had collected £15,000 in fines; and there stands the stately Mansion House to this day, to keep the blushing citizen in mind of a long past and lamented day when a band of Yankees slipped into London and played games of the sort that has given their race a unique and shady reputation among all truly good and holy peoples that be in the earth.
==Architecture== [[File:Mansion House (6385048237).jpg|thumb|The Egyptian Hall in 2011]] Mansion House has three main storeys over a rusticated basement. The entrance facade has a [[portico]] with six [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] columns, supporting a pediment with a tympanum sculpture by Sir Robert Taylor, in the centre of which is a symbolic figure of the City of London trampling on her enemies.{{cite book |last1=Timbs |first1=John |title=Curiosities of London |url= |accessdate= |edition= New |year=1867 |origyear=First edition published 1855 |publisher=J.S. Virtue |location= London|pages=540–1}} The building originally had two prominent and unusual attic structures at either end, which were removed in 1794 and 1843. The building is on a confined site. Sir [[John Summerson]] wrote that "it leaves an impression of uneasily constricted bulk", adding that "on the whole, the building is a striking reminder that good taste was not a universal attribute in the eighteenth century". The main reception room, the columned "Egyptian Hall", was so named because Dance used an arrangement of columns deemed to be "Egyptian" by [[Vitruvius]]. No Egyptian motifs were employed. It has twenty niches for sculpture. There was originally an open courtyard, later occupied by a saloon. The residence used to have its own [[court of law]], since the Lord Mayor is the [[chief magistrate]] of the City while in office. There were eleven holding cells (ten for men and one, nicknamed "the birdcage", for women). A famous prisoner here was the early 20th-century [[suffragette]] women's rights campaigner [[Sylvia Pankhurst]]. ==Art collection== Mansion House is home to [[The Harold Samuel Collection of Dutch and Flemish Seventeenth Century Paintings]], described as "the finest collection of such works to be formed in Britain this century" (Sutton 1992). It consists of 84 paintings and includes some outstanding works by artists including [[Hendrick Avercamp]], [[Gerard Ter Borch]], [[Pieter Claesz]], [[Aelbert Cuyp]], [[Frans Hals]], [[Pieter de Hooch]], [[Jacob van Ruisdael]], [[Jan Steen]], [[David Teniers the Younger]] and [[Willem van de Velde]]. Mansion House also houses a plate collection, which includes among other treasures, the five ceremonial [[City of London swords]]. ==Public access== Mansion House is not generally open to the public. However, tours can be arranged through the diary office, and there are public tours most Tuesdays. ==Mansion House Street== Mansion House Street is the short street at the front of Mansion House, which connects [[Poultry, London|Poultry]], [[Queen Victoria Street, London|Queen Victoria Street]] and [[Bank junction]] above [[Bank–Monument station|Bank Underground station]]. ==Other== [[Guildhall, London|Guildhall]] is another venue used for important City functions. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * Sutton, P. ''Dutch and Flemish Seventeenth Century Paintings: The Harold Samuel Collection'', 1992, Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-41795-3}} and {{ISBN|978-0-521-42840-8}}. ==External links== *[https://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/about-the-city/mansion-house/Pages/default.aspx Official website] {{London landmarks}} [[Category:Grade I listed buildings in the City of London]] [[Category:Georgian architecture in London]] [[Category:Greek Revival houses in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Historic house museums in London]] [[Category:History of the City of London]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1752]] [[Category:Houses in the City of London]] [[Category:Mayors' mansions in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Museums in the City of London]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in London]] [[Category:Scandals in England]] [[Category:Political scandals]] [[Category:Religious scandals]] [[Category:Financial scandals]]

'''Mimicking operations''' is a tactical concept, developed under [[Terrorist Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures]], to explain a form of [[deception]], commonly used by terrorists in their attacks. The concept is commonly used in military tactical modelling and scientific simulation; and is connected to the idea of shielding friendly forces (as well as foes) from detection and deception.<ref name=Flaherty2003>{{cite web |last=Flaherty |first=C. J. |year=December 2003 |title= Mimicking Operations | journal = Australian Army Journal | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 11–14 |url=https://www.army.gov.au/sites/g/files/net1846/f/aaj_2003_2.pdf}}</ref>
== Definition == [[Mimicry|Mimicking]] operations is a – “cost-effective way of achieving a desired operational effect using superior deception tactics to exploit concealment and camouflage opportunities”.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Flaherty |first=C. J. |title=3D tactics and Information Deception |journal= Journal of Information Warfare |date= September 2008 |volume=7 | issue = 27 2 |pages= 49–58 }}</ref>
== Relationship with military deception operations == [[Carlo Kopp]] identified in 2002 that 'deception and Mimicry is the insertion of intentionally misleading information. It amounts to mimicking a known signal so well, that a receiver cannot distinguish the phony signal from the real signal.'<ref name=Flaherty2003/><ref name=Kopp-Mills-2002>{{cite journal |first1=Carlo |last1=Kopp |first2= Bruce |last2=Mills |year=2002 |title=Information Warfare And Evolution |citeseerx = 10.1.1.159.2149 }}</ref>
== Relationship with Fifth Dimension Operations == The mimicking operations concept was acknowledged as an early iteration of [[Fifth Dimension Operations|contemporary Fifth Dimension Operations]].<ref>{{cite book | first1 = Robert J. | last1 = Bunker | first2 = Charles "Sid" | last2 = Heal | date = 2014 | title = Fifth Dimensional Operations: Space-Time-Cyber Dimensionality in Conflict and War—A Terrorism Research Center Book | publisher = iuniverse | url = http://bookstore.iuniverse.com/Products/SKU-000943549/Fifth-Dimensional-Operations.aspx }}</ref>
== Use of examples from nature == The concept of mimicking operations simulates activity that resembles a bacterial attack on a large and complex organism. Attacking cells mimic the behavior of their victims, but remain dormant while awaiting an opportunity to launch an attack.<ref name=Kopp-Mills-2002/> The development of mimicking operations has been influenced by biology, ecology and the workings of the natural world. * A species evolves the appearance of another to aid its survival. * Animals or insects develop a physical similarity to their predators, in order to avoid danger. * Portia spiders strum the webs of other spiders to imitate mating behaviors or the actions of distressed prey.
== Military tactics use == In military tactics, the employment of mimicking operational strategies, is based on concepts: * A potential target is given confusing information and is encouraged to walk into what appears to be a safe situation. * The use of mimicry manipulates information through the simulation of behavior or of physical appearance. * Mimicking operations represents an increasingly cost-effective way of achieving a desired operational effect using superior information to exploit concealment, deception and imitation techniques.
== Mimicking operations as a subset of military deception == Mimicking Operations is a subset of [[military deception]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oodaloop.com/security/2012/09/07/dangerous-minds-the-relationship-between-beliefs-behaviors-and-tactics/ |title=Dangerous Minds - The Relationship between Beliefs, Behaviors, and Tactics |publisher=OODA Loop |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> From a logistics perspective the capacity to develop a deception strategy, reflects the relative capacity of the combatant to collect the resources to develop suitable deception. In the case of [[terrorism]], an individual with few resources is likely to adapt a mimicking strategy, and seek to [[camouflage]] themselves. Whereas a more resourced team of terrorists with the backing of an organisation may be more likely to afford the resources to develop a decoy, as part of a developed deception strategy.

The MoD is headed by the Minister of Defence, a civilian and member of cabinet; the post is usually held by the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, who also serves as the President's second-in-command of the military. The MoD exercises supreme command authority over the [[Bangladesh Armed Forces]]. ==Organisational structure== Parliament is constitutionally responsible for working with the president and the service chiefs in ensuring the nation's defence. In practice, however, members of Parliament have never played a significant role in either national defence planning or defence budgeting, the Defence Secretary does.{{cite book |date=1989 |editor1-last=Heitzman |editor1-first=James |editor2-last=Worden |editor2-first=Robert |chapter=Organization of the Armed Forces|chapter-url= |title=Bangladesh: A Country Study |url=http://countrystudies.us/bangladesh/ |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=Federal Research Division, Library of Congress |pages=218}} ==Agencies and Departments under the Ministry of Defence== * [[Bangladesh Navy]] * [[Bangladesh Air Force]] ===Inter-Forces institutions=== * [[Director Generals of Medical Services]] (DGMS) * [[National Defence College (Bangladesh)|National Defence College]] (NDC) * [[Defence Services Command and Staff College (Bangladesh)|Defence Services Command and Staff College]] (DSCSC) * [[Military Institute of Science and Technology]] (MIST) * [[Bangladesh University of Professionals]] (BUP) * [[Armed Forces Medical College (Bangladesh)|Armed Forces Medical College]] (AFMC) * [[Armed Forces Medical Institute]] (AFMI) * [[Armed Forces Institute of Pathology, Bangladesh|Armed Forces Institute of Pathology]] (AFIP) * [[Bangladesh Ordnance Factories]] (BOF) * [[Inter Services Selection Board (Bangladesh)|Inter Services Selection Board]] (ISSB) * [[Bangladesh Armed Services Board]] (BASB) * [[Directorate General of Defence Purchase]] (DGDP) * [[Directorate General of Forces Intelligence]] (DGFI) * [[Inter-Services Public Relations (Bangladesh)|Inter-Services Public Relations]] (ISPR){{cite web |url=http://www.ispr.gov.bd/content.php?id=about_us |title=About Us |website=Inter-Service Public Relations Directorate |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619052530/http://www.ispr.gov.bd/content.php?id=about_us |archivedate=2015-06-19 |df= }} * [[List of cadet colleges in Bangladesh|Governing Bodies of Cadet |url=http://mod.portal.gov.bd/site/page/f95483d2-a269-46c1-b253-eedce0785751 |script-title=প্রতিরক্ষা মন্ত্রণালয়ের কার্যাবলি |trans-title=The Functions of the Ministry of Defence |language=bn |website=Ministry of Defence}} * Defence of Bangladesh. * Defence Services of Bangladesh and Armed Forces attached to or operating with any of the Armed Forces of Bangladesh excluding planning, co-ordination and arrangement of mobilisation of the defence services on declaration of national emergency/war and co-ordination and control of the activities of the defence services when deployed in aid of civil administration. * Army, Naval and Air Force Works * Production of cypher documents * [[Bangladesh Ordnance Factories]] (Produce Ammunition and Arms for Bangladesh Army) * International and preparation of navigational charts (excluding Hydrographic surveys in the inland water of Bangladesh and preparation of charts for inland navigation) * [[Survey of Bangladesh]] * Budget legal and statutory matters of the Armed Forces * Secretarial administration including financial matters * Administration and control of subordinate offices and organisations under this ministry * Liaison with ministry * Inquires and statistics on any of the subjects allotted to this ministry. * Fees in respect of any of the subjects allotted to this ministry except fees taken in courts ==References== page.title: Movement for the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra

revision.text:
{{close paraphrasing|date=October 2015}} [[Image:Flag of Biafra.svg|right|thumb|Flag of the Republic of Biafra]] The '''Movement for the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra''' ('''MASSOB''') is a [[secession]]ist movement in [[Nigeria]], associated with [[Igbo nationalism]], which supports the recreation of an independent state of [[Biafra]]. It is led by an [[India]]n-trained lawyer [[Ralph Uwazuruike]], with headquarters in [[Okwe]], in the [[Okigwe]] district of [[Imo State]].
MASSOB's leaders say it is a peaceful group and advertise a 25-stage plan to achieve its goal peacefully.<ref name="">{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2006/07/12/dream_of_free_biafra_revives_in_southeast_nigeria/|title=Dream of free Biafra revives in southeast Nigeria|author=Estelle Shirbon|date=2006-07-12|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> There are two arms to the government, the Biafra [[Government in Exile]] and Biafra Shadow Government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biafra.cwis.org/news20090413.php|title=Biafra News - 04.13.2009|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010030754/http://biafra.cwis.org/news20090413.php|archivedate=10 October 2010|df=}}</ref>
The Nigerian government accuses MASSOB of violence; MASSOB's leader, Ralph Uwazuruike, was arrested in 2005 and detained on treason charges; he was released in 2007. MASSOB also championed the release of oil militant [[Mujahid Dokubo-Asari]], who faced similar charges at the time.<ref name="Murray">{{cite news|work=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6657259.stm|title=Reopening Nigeria's civil war wounds|author=Senan Murray|date=2007-05-03|accessdate=2008-08-15}}</ref> In 2009, MASSOB launched "the Biafran International Passport" in response to persistent demand by Biafrans in the [[diaspora]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/07/01/massob-launches-biafran-intl-passport-to-celebrate-10th-anniversary/comment-page-2/|title=MASSOB launches "Biafran Int'l Passport" to celebrate 10th anniversary - Vanguard News|work=Vanguard News|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref>
== Ideology == MASSOB agitates for a Republic of Biafra comprising the South-East and South-South regions of Nigeria; though Uwazuruike has stated in interviews that the Niger Deltans "can have their own republic."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3959&Itemid=41|title=NewsWatchngr|work=NewsWatchngr|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref> The group's philosophy is hinged on the principle of non-violence as propagated by [[Mahatma Gandhi]].
== Activities ==
=== Hoisting of Biafran flags === At its inception, MASSOB concentrated on organizing rallies and peaceful protests which culminated in hoisting Biafran flags at different locations in the South East. In recent years, this practice has been reserved mainly for celebrating key dates and events or in commemoration of dead members.
=== Protests === MASSOB members embark on protests to protest arrests and killings of its members. In one of these protests, the house of the late Nigerian leader, Nnamdi Azikiwe, was torched. The then Secretary-General of [[Ohanaeze Ndigbo]], Col. Joe Achuzie (rtd) exonerated MASSOB from blame and accused the security agents of "carelessness and irresponsibility."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nm.onlinenigeria.com/templates/?a=5932&z=12 |title=Zik: Ohanaeze absolves MASSOB from blame, calls for probe |publisher=Nm.onlinenigeria.com |date=2005-11-09 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref>
=== Re-introduction of the Biafran currency === In 2005, MASSOB re-introduced the old Biafran currency into circulation. This sparked a lot of excitement at the time especially as one Biafran pound was said to exchange for two hundred and seventy naira at the border communities of Togo and the Republic of Benin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/Cover/10801133924.htm|title=NewsWatchngr|work=NewsWatchngr|accessdate=20 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130208140833/http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/Cover/10801133924.htm|archivedate=8 February 2013|df=}}</ref> In his reaction, the then President of Nigeria, Olusegun Obasanjo, likened the Biafran pounds to a collector's item and attributed its high exchange value to its relative rarity.
=== Introduction of the Biafran passport === MASSOB launched the Biafran passport in 2009 as part of the program to celebrate its 10th anniversary. MASSOB leader, Ralph Uwazuruike, said the introduction of the Biafran passport was in response to persistent demands from Biafrans in diaspora.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/07/massob-launches-biafran-intl-passport-to-celebrate-10th-anniversary/|title=MASSOB launches "Biafran Int'l Passport" to celebrate 10th anniversary - Vanguard News|work=Vanguard News|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref>
== Nigerian government response == Since its inception, MASSOB has continually alleged mass arrests and killings of its members by government forces. According to the group's sanitation grassroot information spokesperson, Kelechi A Chukwu, the government forces allegedly carries out secret executions of MASSOB members in detention centres and prisons nationwide. In May 2008, the group released a list of 2,020 members alleged to have been killed by security agents since 1999. MASSOB leader, Ralph Uwazuruike, has been arrested on several occasions and charged with treason. In 2011, Uwazuruike and 280 MASSOB members were arrested in Enugu while attending a function in honour of Ojukwu. Few days later, President Goodluck Jonathan ordered Uwazuruike's release as well as all other MASSOB members in detention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enugustatedirect.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=932%3Ajonathan-orders-release-of-uwazuruike-massob-members-from-detention&catid=1%3Alatest&Itemid=28|title=Jonathan orders release of Uwazuruike, MASSOB members from detention|author=Administrator|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref>
In June 2012, the Human Rights Writers' Association of Nigeria condemned the alleged killing of 16 members of MASSOB by security agencies in Anambra.
In February 2013, MASSOB claimed that several corpses found floating in the Ezu River on the boundary of Enugu and Anambra States were those of its members previously arrested by the police.<ref>{{cite web |last=Reporter |first=Our |url=http://sunnewsonline.com/new/cover/ezu-river-corpses-victims-were-our-members-massob/ |title=Ezu River corpses: Victims were our members – MASSOB |publisher=Sunnewsonline.com |date=2013-02-08 |accessdate=2016-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705130813/http://sunnewsonline.com/new/cover/ezu-river-corpses-victims-were-our-members-massob/ |archivedate=2013-07-05 |df= }}</ref> The group claimed that the police routinely executed MASSOB members without proper trial.
On September 13, 2015 police in Anambra state arrested no fewer than 25 MOSSAB members who were marking their 16th anniversary; one MASSOB member was shot. At St Charles Lwanga Catholic Church Okpoko,18 members were arrested and one shot and at Iba Pope Catholic Church, while at Awada, 11 members of MASSOB were arrested. At Awka, two MASSOB were arrested by the police according to the MASSOB former Deputy Director of Information, Mazi Chris Mocha<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/09/pandemonium-as-police-massob-clash-during-16th-anniversary-service/ |title=Pandemonium as police, MASSOB clash during 16th anniversary service - Vanguard News |publisher=Vanguardngr.com |date=2015-09-14 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref>
On May 31, 2013, President Goodluck Jonathan, a Niger Deltan Ijaw from Bayelsa State and from the South-South geopolitical zone, branded MASSOB to be one of three extremist groups threatening the security of Nigeria. Jonathan declared that “the Nigerian state faces three fundamental security challenges posed by extremist groups like Boko Haram in the North; the Movement for the Actualisation of the Sovereign State of Biafra in the South-East; and the Oodua People’s Congress in the South-West."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/news/fg-may-clamp-down-on-massob-opc/|title=FG may clamped down on MASSOB, OPC|author=|publisher=The Punch|accessdate=21 May 2013 www.informationanambra.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925103933/http://www.punchng.com/news/fg-may-clamp-down-on-massob-opc/|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta]] * [[Niger Delta People's Volunteer Force]] * [[Nigeria-Biafra War]] * [[Oodua Republic Front]] * [[Republic of Biafra]] * Movement for the Emancipation of the Middle belt (Federal Republic of Kwararafa)

Ben-Shaul|title=A Violent World: TV News Images of Middle Eastern Terror and War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QFBiclfUJ04C&pg=PA106|year=2007|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-3799-6|pages=106–}}</ref> | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = [[Media watch group]] | headquarters = | location = [[Israel]] | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = Founding director | leader_name = [[Itamar Marcus]] | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | budget = | num_staff = 12 ''<small>(2012)</small>''<ref>{{cite news|last=Dovere|first=Maxine|title=Exposing the Palestinian media|url=http://www.jpost.com/Features/InThespotlight/Article.aspx?id=270555|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=19 May 2012}}</ref> | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|www.palwatch.org}} | remarks = | former name = }}
'''Palestinian Media Watch''' ('''PMW'''; {{Lang-he|מבט לתקשורת פלסטינית}}) is an Israel-based nongovernmental organization and [[media watchdog group]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Pincus|first=Walter|title=Plan for Terror Screening of Aid Groups Cut Drastically|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/29/AR2007082901913.html|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=30 August 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Palestinian Hamas takes Mickey|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6637389.stm|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=9 May 2007}}</ref> Founded in 1996 by [[Itamar Marcus]], Palestinian Media Watch documents cases of incitement in Palestinian media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kershner|first=Isabel|authorlink=Isabel Kershner|title=Finding Fault in the Palestinian Messages That Aren't So Public|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/20/world/middleeast/palestinian-messages-dont-match-israeli-group-says.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Matti|title=UNESCO cuts funds for Palestinian magazine|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/10009198|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=23 December 2011|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]}}</ref> It describes itself as "an Israeli research institute that studies Palestinian society from a broad range of perspectives by monitoring and analyzing the Palestinian Authority through its media and schoolbooks."<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.palwatch.org/pages/aboutus.aspx|publisher=Palestinian Media Watch|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref>
== Reports to Western political bodies == After a period during which Palestinian television was airing music videos promoting martyrdom and encouraging violence against U.S. troops in Iraq, in 2003 Itamar Marcus testified in front of a [[List of United States Senate committees|U.S. Senate committee]] hearing to discuss the phenomenon. Marcus characterized one of the videos shown at the hearing as "Palestinians...glorifying the killing of American soldiers" and calling on Iraqis "to kill American soldiers." [[American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee]] communications director [[Hussein Ibish]] agreed that another video encouraged Palestinian children to commit suicide but said that only 3% of Palestinians watch Palestinian television and that a seven-minute peace song was also being aired regularly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Transcripts: Paula Zahn Now|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0310/30/pzn.00.html|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=30 October 2003}}</ref>
In 2007, Palestinian Media Watch presented the [[Select committees of the Parliament of the United Kingdom|U.K. Parliament Select Committee]] on the European Union with evidence pertaining to Palestinian schoolbooks it said reject Israel's right to exist, glorify terrorism, and inculcate youngsters with hatred for Israel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorandum by Palestinian Media Watch (PMW)|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200607/ldselect/ldeucom/132/132we06.htm|publisher=[[Parliament of the United Kingdom]]|accessdate=26 June 2012|date=March 2007}}</ref>
A report Palestinian Media Watch presented to the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs]] in 2008 indicated that the [[Palestinian Authority]] was engaging with enemies of the United States on a shared platform of hatred toward the U.S. The report argued that under such circumstances the creation of an independent Palestinian state would contribute to the undermining U.S. efforts toward [[world peace]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Keinon|first=Herb|title=PMW: PA cozying up to America's enemie|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast//Article.aspx?id=98327|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=16 April 2008}}</ref>
In 2011 Palestinian Media Watch presented U.S. congressmen with a report indicating that more than {{Nowrap|$5 million}} of U.S. funding for the Palestinian Authority was being used to pay salaries to [[Palestinian_prisoners_of_Israel|Palestinian prisoners]] jailed in Israel on terrorism-related charges. The report also cited instances of the Palestinian Authority glorifying the perpetrators of terrorist attacks against Israelis.<ref>{{cite news|last=Keinon|first=Herb|title='US paying salaries for jailed Palestinian terrorists'|url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=231103|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=26 July 2011|authorlink=Herb Keinon|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020145713/http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=231103|archivedate=20 October 2012|df=}}</ref>
== Reports to Israeli security bodies == In 2012, ''[[Haaretz]]'' reported that as a consequence of Israeli intelligence agencies having reduced their own real-time monitoring of mainstream Arab-language media, Palestinian Media Watch and the [[Washington, D.C.]]-based [[Middle East Media Research Institute]] provide the Israeli government with coverage of anti-Israel incitement in the Palestinian media. The Prime Minister's Bureau has stated that prior to the government citing information furnished by the two organizations, the source of the material and its credibility are verified.<ref name="H12">{{cite news|last=Ravid|first=Barak|title=Officials: Israel outsources monitoring of Palestinian media after IDF lapse|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/officials-israel-outsources-monitoring-of-palestinian-media-after-idf-lapse-1.410082|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=[[Haaretz]]|date=31 January 2012}}</ref>
==Use by mainstream press==
International media regularly cite and quote PMW translations as accurate representations of Palestinian Arabic-language media. News organizations that cite PMW as a source include: ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''<ref name=Huntley>{{cite news|last1=Huntley|first1=Steve|title=Decimated Hamas makes ludicrous claims|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/uncategorized/7/71/208846/decimated-hamas-makes-ludicrous-claims/|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=Chicago Sun-Times|date=7 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=Huntley2>{{cite news|last1=Huntley|first1=Steve|title=Huntley: Verdict affirms blood-soaked history of Palestinian terrorism|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/403697/hunt|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=Chicago Sun Times|date=28 February 2015}}</ref> the [[Associated Press]],<ref name=Deitch>{{cite news|last1=Deitch|first1=Ian|title=Israel takes aim at Palestinian 'incitement'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/03/AR2010110305824.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Washington Post|date=3 November 2010}}</ref><ref name=PETA>{{cite news|last1=Deitch|first1=Ian|title=PETA Critiques Hamas TV for Animal Abuse|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/15/AR2007081501495.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Washington Post|date=15 August 2007}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''<ref name=membership>{{cite news|title=Russia vows to support Palestinian UN membership bid|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/palestinianauthority/8778069/Russia-vows-to-support-Palestinian-UN-membership-bid.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=21 September 2011}}</ref><ref name=Simmons>{{cite news|last1=Simmons|first1=Jake|title=Palestinians reward terrorists from British aid|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/palestinianauthority/10790490/Palestinians-reward-terrorists-from-British-aid.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=27 April 2014}}</ref> and ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name=Pincus>{{cite news|last1=Pincus|first1=Walter|title=Plan for Terror Screening of Aid Groups Cut Drastically|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/29/AR2007082901913.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=30 August 2007}}</ref>
== Media monitoring ==
=== 2007–2012 === In 2007 widespread criticism was generated around a children's television program, ''[[Tomorrow's Pioneers]]'', aired from Hamas-run studios in the Gaza Strip.<ref>{{cite news|last=McGregor-Wood|first=Simon|title=Bye, Bye Mickey! Hamas TV Abuzz Over Nahoul the Bee|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=3384547#.T-njm5Fq1Ns|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[ABC News]]|date=17 July 2007|quote=But after the widespread criticism, Hamas eventually killed off Farfour the mouse, and it was done in brutal, predictably political style.}}</ref> The program employed a [[Mickey Mouse]]-inspired figure in order to instill anti-American and anti-Israeli sentiment and promote a message of Islamic dominion among children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mickey Mouse Rip-Off Spreads Hamas Message|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-202_162-2775292.html|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=11 February 2009|agency=[[The Associated Press]]}}</ref> Palestinian Media Watch, together with the [[Middle East Media Research Institute]] (MEMRI), were the first to raise concerns in relation to the show.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shubert|first=Atika|title=Hamas kids TV show with militant mouse to air Friday|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2007-05-10/world/mideast.mouse_1_barghouti-al-aqsa-television-hamas/2?_s=PM:WORLD|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=10 May 2007|authorlink=Atika Shubert}}</ref>
In 2008 Palestinian Media Watch generated outrage again when it circulated a recording of ''Tomorrow's Pioneers'' in which a [[Bugs Bunny]]-like figure proclaimed, "I will eat the Jews."<ref>{{cite news|last=Kalman|first=Matthew|title=Hamas launches TV Bugs Bunny-lookalike who declares 'I will eat the Jews'|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-513925/Hamas-launches-TV-Bugs-Bunny-lookalike-declares-I-eat-Jews.html|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[Mail Online]]|date=12 February 2008}}</ref>
A Palestinian Media Watch report from 2012 stated that a [[puppet show]] performed in front of Palestinian children and sponsored by the [[United Nations]]-funded organization [[Burj al Luq Luq Community Centre and Society]] called on children to take up arms in lieu of cigarettes. A separate report from the same year stated that two television hosts from the [[Palestinian Youth Association for Leadership and Rights Activation]] (PYALARA), an organization that receives funding from the [[European Commission Humanitarian Aid Office]], [[Save the Children|Save the Children U.K.]] and [[Cordaid]], described suicide bombers as "the greatest role models for us" during a weekly TV program. The Burj al Luq Luq website was subsequently taken offline, and Save the Children U.K. launched an investigation into PYALARA.<ref>{{cite news|last=Quinn|first=Melissa|title=UN-backed NGO urges kids to replace cigarettes with guns|url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/06/13/un-backed-ngo-urges-kids-to-replace-cigarettes-with-guns/|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Daily Caller]]|date=13 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Burke|first=Solomon|title=PA, EU, and UN Affiliated Orgs Sponsor Hate-Filled Programs For Palestinian Youth|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/israel/pa-eu-and-un-affiliated-orgs-sponsor-hate-filled-programs-for-palestinian-youth/2012/06/13/|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jewish Press]]|date=13 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ya'ar|first=Chana|title=PMW's 'Puppet Show' Report Shuts Down PA Website|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/156882#.T-oKbZFq1Ns|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=14 June 2012}}</ref>
=== 2013 === In early 2013 a report by Palestinian Media Watch indicating that the Palestinian Authority glorified acts of terrorism against the State of Israel sparked debate in [[Norway]] over the latter's contribution to the PA of some {{Nowrap|$52.5 million}} annually. ''[[NRK]]'', the Norwegian [[public broadcasting]] network, used the PMW report in its coverage and stated that according to the [[Norwegian Center for Studies of Holocaust and Religious Minorities]] a Palestinian television channel, partly controlled by the Palestinian Authority, occasionally conveys hatred and demonization towards Israel. ''NRK'' reported that programs broadcast on Palestinian television praise prisoners involved in killing Israeli civilians. ''NRK'' also conducted a survey of its own in Jerusalem and the [[West Bank]], finding among other things that several Palestinians believed the ''[[Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]'' forgery is authentic and that it reflects "Jewish plans" for world domination.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norway questions funding of PA after Palestinian Media Watch findings|url=http://www.thejewishchronicle.net/pages/full_story/push?article-+Norway+questions+funding+of+PA+after+Palestinian+Media+Watch+findings+%20&id=21840816|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=The Jewish Chronicle (Pittsburgh)|agency=JNS.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Shwayder|first=Maya|title=Salaries For Suicide Bombers: Western States Unwittingly Fund Terrorist Activities In Palestine, Says Report|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/salaries-suicide-bombers-western-states-unwittingly-fund-terrorist-activities-palestine-says-report|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=14 February 2013}}</ref> The Norwegian Holocaust Center, which also contributed money to the Palestinian Authority, said PA TV demonized Israel and spread antisemitism.<ref name=NN>{{cite news|title=Norwegian MP concerned over Norway's "indirect" funding of Palestinian terrorism|url=http://www.norwaynews.com/en/~view.php?72Tb254bP94836u285Vmf844QR2887Rt76ADk353R5T8|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=Norway News|date=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Norwegian Holocaust Center Accuses PA TV of Anti-Semitism|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/breaking-news/norwegian-holocaust-center-accuses-pa-tv-of-anti-semitism/2013/02/12/|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=[[The Jewish Press]]|date=12 February 2013}}</ref>
Emad Alsafar, the program director of the Palestinian television channel, denied the charges of demonization and antisemitism stating that Palestinians took issues with the occupation, not with Jews. He said that in live broadcasts undesirable views are occasionally expressed, but there is an effort to correct these in retrospect. Norwegian State Secretary [[Torgeir Larsen]] admitted that Palestinian Media Watch had presented examples of antisemitism but stated that these were examples and that PMW had their own agenda in presenting the material. In relation to an additional ''NRK'' report on claims made by PMW that the Palestinian Authority pays monthly salaries to Palestinians convicted of terrorist activities including murder, the Norwegian Foreign Ministry felt it important to state that PMW is on the right wing of Israeli politics and that its founder, Itamar Marcus, resides in an illegal settlement in the West Bank.<ref name=NN/><ref name=NRK2>{{cite news|last=Strand|first=Tormand|title=Hevder palestinske myndigheter lønner fengslede terrorister|trans-title=Claims Palestinian Authority pays imprisoned terrorists|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/verden/1.10931411|accessdate=2013-03-15|newspaper=NRK|date=2013-02-28|type=or: [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=no&u=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/verden/1.10931411&prev=/search%3Fq%3DPMW%2Bsite:nrk.no%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26hs%3DXpG%26sa%3DX%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official%26biw%3D1366%26bih%3D583&sa=X&ei=PHNDUYPDAfPL0AXf6YEw&ved=0CGAQ7gEwBQ Google translate]}}</ref> Norwegian MP [[Peter Skovholt Gitmark|Peter Gitmark]] subsequently called on his parliament's [[Standing Committee on Scrutiny and Constitutional Affairs|scrutiny committee]] to investigate the matter of what he called Norway's "indirect" contribution to Palestinian terrorism.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwegian MP concerned over Norway's "indirect" funding of Palestinian terrorism|url=http://www.thecommentator.com/article/2873/norwegian_mp_concerned_over_norway_s_indirect_funding_of_palestinian_terrorism|accessdate=23 March 2013|newspaper=TheCommentator|date=7 March 2013}}</ref>
In 2013, an Israeli family sued Palestinian officials for responsibility for "incitement against Israel which led to “terrorist” attacks against Israel and Israelis" in a [[Tel Aviv]] district court. Itamar Marcus was called as "expert witness", but Judge Dalia Gannot found Marcus “incompetent” as such. The Media Watch further argued that “the PA follows an explicit policy of incitement against Israel and the Jews,” but Judge Gannot found that to be unproven. The case against the Palestinian officials was dismissed.<ref>[http://www.maannews.com/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?id=629247 Israel court rejects media watchdog 'incitement' charge], 12/09/2013, Ma’an; also cited in [http://electronicintifada.net/blogs/asa-winstanley/palestinian-media-watchs-biased-director-no-expert-rules-israeli-court Palestinian Media Watch’s “biased” director no expert, rules Israeli court], Asa Winstanley, 09/13/2013, [[Electronic Intifada]]</ref>
=== 2014 - present === {{empty section|date=January 2018}}
== YouTube channel == In December 2010 [[YouTube]] removed Palestinian Media Watch's channel from its servers. The channel, which featured videos of Palestinian incitement against Jews and Israelis, was shut down for airing [[hate speech]]. Itamar Marcus stated that the move was triggered by a video showing a Hamas terrorist urging Palestinians to "drink the blood of Jews."<ref>{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Ron|title=YouTube removes Israeli media watchdog's channel|url=http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?id=200177|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=20 December 2010}}</ref> The channel was reactivated later in the month after supporters expressed outrage over its removal.<ref>{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Ron|title=YouTube reactivates Palestinian Media Watch channel|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=200260|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=20 December 2010}}</ref>
== Reception == According to a 2012 article in ''[[Haaretz]]'', Palestinian Media Watch and its founder are associated with Israel's right wing, and the majority of information furnished by PMW relating to Palestinian incitement is of a professional nature.<ref name="H12"/>
In an opinion piece for ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', [[Hanan Ashrawi]] of the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] accused Palestinian Media Watch of having close links with the [[Central Fund of Israel]], which she said was involved in funding "some of the most extreme elements in Israel's settler movement." Ashrawi stated also that the PMW definition of incitement included "any action or statement critical of Israeli policy" such as nonviolent actions against Israeli occupation or in support of Palestinian rights.<ref name="Ashrawi 2010">{{cite web | last=Ashrawi | first=Dr. Hanan | title=Stop the rhetoric and let’s start talking now | website=TheHill | date=2010-05-11 | url=http://thehill.com/opinion/op-ed/97277-stop-the-rhetoric-and-lets-start-talking-now | access-date=2018-01-27}}</ref> In an article for ''[[CounterPunch]]'', [[Samah Sabawi]] described PMW as a right-wing propaganda site.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.counterpunch.org/2006/02/23/hamas-and-the-missing-video/ | title = Hamas and the Missing Video | publisher= counterpunch.org | accessdate= 2009-12-07}}</ref>
[[Australia–Israel relations|Australia's former ambassador to Israel]] [[Ian Wilcock]], in an opinion piece for ''[[The Australian]]'', said of Palestinian Media Watch that it "does an outstanding job of bringing attention to what the [[Palestinian Authority]] and related organisations are saying in Arabic, as opposed to the usually more temperate comments made in English for the world outside the Middle East." As examples Wilcock stated that ''[[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]'' was prominent in the ideology of the Palestinian Authority, that a Palestinian Authority youth magazine had featured a young woman dreaming of explaining to Adolf Hitler why she killed Jews, and that a Palestinian Authority newspaper had referred to [[Passover]] as "the holiday of the apes."<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilcock|first=Ian|title=Anti-Semitism still a roadblock to peace|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/opinion/anti-semitism-still-a-roadblock-to-peace/story-e6frgd0x-1226471370621|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=11 September 2012}}</ref>
==Award== In February 2015, PMW director was awarded the Abramowitz Israeli Prize for Media Criticism.<ref>{{cite web | author=JNS.org | title=Palestinian Media Watch Director to Receive Media Criticism Prize | website=Algemeiner.com | date=2015-02-10 | url=https://www.algemeiner.com/2015/02/10/palestinian-media-watch-director-to-receive-media-criticism-prize/ | access-date=2018-01-27}}</ref> The ''Abramowitz Israeli Prize for Media Criticism'' was funded by Mrs. Nira and Mr. Kenneth Abramowitz.<ref>[http://www.imw.org.il/english/article.php?id=52 The Abramowitz Israeli Prize for Media Criticism]</ref> Mr. Kenneth Abramowitz is a New York businessman, and a donor to Israel’s Media Watch.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/misc/iphone-article/new-alternative-zionist-fund-supporting-right-wing-settler-groups-1.405848 New 'alternative Zionist fund' supporting right-wing settler groups], Uri Blau, 06.01.12, [[Haaretz]]</ref>
==See also== *[[Al-Aqsa TV]] *''[[Deception: Betraying the Peace Process]]'' *[[Pallywood]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} In the [[Parliament of Australia]], the political parties appoint '''party whips''' to ensure [[party discipline]], help manage legislative business and carry out a variety of other functions on behalf of the party leadership. The most important function of a government party [[whip (politics)|whip]] is to ensure that a sufficient number of members and senators are present to take part in votes in the chamber, to maintain a [[Quorum#Australia|parliamentary quorum]] and to prevent [[censure motion]]s succeeding.<ref>Parliamentary Education Office. [http://www.peo.gov.au/students/fss/fss26.html Fact Sheet 36: The Party Whip].</ref> Their roles in the chamber include taking divisions, and arranging [[Pair (parliamentary convention)|pairs]] which affects the ability of members and senators to leave parliament during sittings, as well as the entitlement to be absent during divisions.
Unlike in the [[Chief Whip|United Kingdom]], Australian whips do not hold official office, but they are recognised for parliamentary purposes. In practice, Australian whips play a lesser role than their counterparts in the United Kingdom, as party discipline in Australia tends to be tighter.<ref>Parliament of Australia: Parliamentary Library. [http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/Publications_Archive/CIB/cib0203/03CIB01 Free Votes in Australian and some Overseas Parliaments].</ref> The role of the whip becomes more critical the lower the majority the government has in the [[lower house]] of Parliament.
[[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] whips are appointed by the leader of the party, while [[Australian Labor Party]] whips are elected by the [[Caucus]]. For Labor and the Liberals, the chief whip is assisted by two deputy whips.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Parliamentary Education Office |url=http://www.peo.gov.au/students/fact_sheets/party_whip.html |title=Fact Sheet – Party Whips |accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref>
Similar arrangements exist in the six state and the two self-governing territory parliaments.
==Duties== Whips are essential to the day-to-day running of the house. They assist the party business managers (the [[Leader of the House (Australia)|Leader of the House]], [[Manager of Opposition Business in the House (Australia)|Manager of Opposition Business in the House]], [[Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Australia)|Manager of Government Business in the Senate]], and [[Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate (Australia)|Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate]] and their four deputies) arrange the order of business on the floor. They also draw up lists of speakers in debates, which (though not binding) assist the occupant of the chair in deciding whom to call on. The whips play the primary role in managing business in the parallel debating chamber (the [[Australian House of Representatives#Federation Chamber|Federation Chamber]]). The Government Chief Whip has the same power as ministers and parliamentary secretaries to move business motions. This right was extended with the creation of the parallel chamber (then called the Main Committee) to facilitate movement of business between it and the floor of the House of Representatives. The right can also be exercised by another whip acting on the Chief Whip's behalf.<ref>{{cite book |title=House of Representatives Practice |chapter=Chapter 2. The House, Government and Opposition |pages=55–56 |accessdate=27 August 2013 |edition=6th |editor=Wright, B. C. |publisher=Department of the House of Representatives |year=2012 |chapter-url=http://www.aph.gov.au/~/media/05%20About%20Parliament/53%20HoR/532%20PPP/Practice6/PDF/Chapters/6Chap02.ashx}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/House_of_Representatives/Powers_practice_and_procedure/00_-_Infosheets/Infosheet_19_-_The_House_-_Government_and_Opposition |title=Infosheet 19: The House, Government and Opposition |publisher=House of Representatives |accessdate=27 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904102223/http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/House_of_Representatives/Powers_practice_and_procedure/00_-_Infosheets/Infosheet_19_-_The_House_-_Government_and_Opposition |archivedate=4 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |work=Fact Sheet |publisher=Parliamentary Education Office |url=http://www.peo.gov.au/students/fact_sheets/party_whip.html |title=Party Whips |accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref>
Whips also play a central role in voting. During each vote (or "division"), whips ensure that their fellow party members are present and seated on the correct side of the house while votes are counted. Acting as tellers, the whips also count the votes. In a typical vote in the House of Representatives, where the Government and Opposition are on opposite sides, each will provide two tellers. One Government whip and one Opposition whip will count the votes in favour of the motion, and the other two will count the votes against.{{#tag:ref|A House of Representatives source on the topic claims the appointment of two tellers is "the recent practice",<ref>{{cite book |chapter-url=http://www.aph.gov.au/binaries/house/pubs/gtp/pdf/chapter9.pdf |chapter=Chapter 9. Divisions |title=Guide to Procedures |author=Department of the House of Representatives |publisher=House of Representatives Printing Office |edition=4th |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> but two tellers have been appointed from the first division on 5 June 1901<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=5 June 1901 |page=729 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%221900s%22%20Year%3A%221901%22%20Month%3A%2206%22%20Day%3A%2205%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref> and in subsequent decades.<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=2 June 1921 |page=8794 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%221920s%22%20Year%3A%221921%22%20Month%3A%2206%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref><ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=2 July 1941 |page=715 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%221940s%22%20Year%3A%221941%22%20Month%3A%2207%22%20Day%3A%2202%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref><ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=17 May 1961 |page=2024 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%221960s%22%20Year%3A%221961%22%20Month%3A%2205%22%20Day%3A%2217%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref><ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=5 June 1981 |page=3236 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%221980s%22%20Year%3A%221981%22%20Month%3A%2206%22%20Day%3A%2205%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref><ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=4 June 2001 |page=27142 |speaker=Division |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22house%20divided%22%20Decade%3A%222000s%22%20Year%3A%222001%22%20Month%3A%2206%22%20Day%3A%2204%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref>|group=n}} In the Senate, each side provides one whip.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Chapter 11. Voting and divisions: Divisions |title=Odger's Australian Senate Practice |edition=13th |accessdate=27 August 2013 |chapter-url=http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Senate/Powers_practice_n_procedures/odgers13?file=chapter11&section=04}}</ref>
==History== Whips have been a part of the Federal Parliament since its beginning with much the same function as today.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article100199834 |title=The First Federal Whip – Mr. Austin Chapman M.P. |work=The Braidwood Dispatch and Mining Journal |location=Braidwood, NSW |page=2 |date=8 June 1901 |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113896330 |title=How Parliament is Stage-Managed |page=6 |date=26 October 1907 |accessdate=15 August 2013|newspaper=Evening News (Sydney, Nsw : 1869 - 1931) }}</ref> Early in its first session in 1901, each of the three parliamentary parties elected one whip in the House of Representatives.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79161588 |title=Today: Meetings |work=The Northern Miner |location=Charters Towers, Qld |date=25 June 1901 |page=2 |accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=13 August 2013 |date=11 May 1901 |page=2 |work=Bathurst Free Press and Mining Journal |title=Opposition Caucus, Mr. Reid Leader, Mr. Smith Whip |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64460263}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=13 August 2013 |date=18 May 1901 |page=4 |work=Singleton Argus |title=Government Whip |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article78911205}}</ref> Labor and the Free Trade Party each appointed a whip in the Senate as well.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=22 August 2014 |page=2 |work=The Northern Miner |location=Charters Towers, Qld |title=To-day |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79161588|date=1901-06-25 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=22 August 2014 |date=24 May 1901 |page=3 |work=The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times |location=Devonport and Burnie, Tas |title=General News: Notes from Melbourne |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64374236}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=31 August 1901 |page=8 |work=Australian Town and Country Journal |location=Sydney |title=The Commonwealth Parliament |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71471534}}</ref> The Protectionist Party, which formed the Government, did not appoint a whip because it did not require the confidence of the Senate to survive,<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=25 May 1901 |page=14 |work=Australian Town and Country Journal |location=Sydney |title=Political Items |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71467642}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=20 May 1901 |page=6 |work=The Argus |location=Melbourne |title=Government "Whip" |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10551340}}</ref> though a whip was subsequently appointed for a brief period.{{#tag:ref|[[John Keating (Australian politician)|John Keating]] was initially appointed to act for the ministry, not the party, solely during the pendency of the tariff bill.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=1 May 1902 |page=5 |work=The West Australian |location=Perth |title=Federal Affairs: The Governor-General's Establishment |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24744112}}</ref> However, he seems to have acted as a more traditional whip by the press during that session.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=10 September 1902 |page=1 |work=The Argus |location=Melbourne |title=No title |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article9084661}}</ref> Keating continued as whip into the following session,<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=21 September 1903 |page=6 |work=Bendigo Advertiser |location=Vic |title=The Federal Capital Sites |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article89607031}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=27 August 2013 |date=3 October 1903 |page=5 |work=The Argus |location=Melbourne |title=Both Our Houses |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10575209}}</ref> though it is not clear whether the arrangement persisted when the Protectionists went into opposition in 1904. At the latest, Keating ceased to be whip upon becoming a minister in July 1905.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ministries and Cabinets |work=Parliamentary Handbook |publisher=Australian Parliamentary Library |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;page=0;query=Scullin%20Ministry%20(ALP);rec=0;resCount=Default |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> No Government whip was appointed.<ref name=ProtNone>{{Cite news |accessdate=August 2013 |date=20 August 1906 |page=4 |work=The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times |location=Devonport and Burnie, Tas |title=Senator Keating |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65149485}}</ref>|group=n}}
While references to assistant or deputy whips in the Australian Parliament sometimes appeared in early press reporting, just when the concept of a deputy whip emerged, or how formal the position initially was, is unclear. For example, [[Alfred Conroy]] was described in a news report in 1903 as Labor's assistant whip,<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article98761228 |title=Political Notes |work=Goulburn Evening Penny Post |location=Goulburn, NSW |date=26 November 1903 |page=4 }}</ref> and when the Labor Whip [[Jim Page (politician)|Jim Page]] died in 1921, press reports stated that "the Deputy Whip", [[James Fenton (Australian politician)|James Fenton]], would act as whip until a new whip was elected.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=7 August 2013 |title=Maranoa Vacancy |page=9 |date=13 June 1921 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |quote=No action has yet been taken to fill the position of Opposition Whip, so ably filled by Mr. Page. For the present, the Deputy Whip, Mr. Fenton, will act. |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15958558}}</ref> There is, however, no indication that he was elected to that position or that any Labor deputy whip was elected until Labor Whip [[Gil Duthie]] successfully lobbied for the official creation of the role in the 1960s.<ref name=DuthieSpeech>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=21 November 1968 |page=3112 |speaker=[[Gil Duthie]] |position=Opposition Whip |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20Decade%3A%221960s%22%20Year%3A%221968%22%20%22deputy%20whip%22;rec=1;resCount=Default}}</ref>
The appointment of a second official whip in the House of Representatives appears to have begun with the [[Commonwealth Liberal Party]], as its appointment of "joint Ministerial whips" in 1913 drew comment.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=13 August 2013 |date=11 July 1913 |page=6 |work=Queensland Times |title=Federal Topics: Liberal Whips Appointed |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113103567}}</ref> Those appointments survived the party's fall from government and merger with National Labor to form the [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist Party]]. The practice continued until 1923, when the Nationalists and [[National Party of Australia|Country Party]] formed a coalition, at which point each party contributed one whip. Unlike later practice, the senior whip (also sometimes called "Chief Government Whip") was the one who had served longer as whip.<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=9 August 2013 |work=The Brisbane Courier |date=30 July 1929 |page=18 |title=To the Editor: Federal Parliamentary Salaries |author=James Hunter MP |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21432191}}</ref> By the 1950s, the Country Party whip was always junior.
It is unclear whether the practice continued when the parties went into opposition in 1929, but when the [[United Australia Party]] was formed from the Nationalists and some breakaway Labor MPs, a member of the latter group became deputy to [[James Bayley (politician)|James Bayley]], who had been the Commonwealth Liberal whip. When the UAP and Country Party formed a new coalition following the 1931 election, they resumed the practice of each party appointing one of two Government whips.
The [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]], formed in 1945, appointed [[Reginald Swartz]] as its first deputy whip in 1950, after the party had won government for the first time. This second Liberal whip was the "Assistant Government Whip", as opposed to the Country Party's whip, who was the "Deputy Government Whip".<ref>See, e.g., {{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=8 September 1971 |speaker=Winton Turnbull |position=Country Party Whip |page=919 |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22assistant%20whip%22%20Decade%3A%221970s%22;rec=1;resCount=Default}}</ref> The [[Australian Labor Party|Labor Party]] elected its first official deputy whip in the early 1960s.{{#tag:ref|Labor Whip Gil Duthie stated in a debate in October 1968 that the Labor Party had elected its first deputy "four or five years ago", i.e. 1963 or 1964.<ref name=DuthieSpeech /> The party's first Senate deputy whip was appointed in 1962,<ref name=LabSenDep /> meaning a House of Representatives whip may have been elected at the same time, in which case Duthie's estimate of the length of time was mistaken.|group=n}}
The first deputy whip in the Senate was [[Annabelle Rankin]] in 1950. She had served as the Liberal Party's whip during the three-year period beginning 1 July 1947, when there were two Liberals senators and one from the Country Party,{{#tag:ref|[[Walter Cooper (politician)|Walter Cooper]] (Country) was [[Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Australia)|Leader of the Opposition in the Senate]], and [[Neil O'Sullivan]] (Liberal) was Deputy Leader.|group=n}} In a somewhat controversial move,<ref>{{Cite news |accessdate=22 August 2014 |date=26 May 1950 |page=3 |work=The Courier-Mail |location=Brisbane |title=Chivalry bid in Senate |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49728899}}</ref> but she was replaced as whip by [[Reg Wright]] and made deputy when senators elected as part of the expansion of the Senate took their seats in February 1950. The next year, following the [[double dissolution]] and [[Australian federal election, 1951|subsequent election]], Wright stood down as whip, and Rankin was elected unopposed to succeed him. The post of deputy was left unfilled.
Labor elected its first deputy Senate whip in 1962.<ref name=LabSenDep>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |date=20 February 1962 |page=14 |speaker=[[Nick McKenna]] |position=[[Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Australia)|Leader of the Opposition in the Senate]] |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansards,hansards80%20Decade%3A%221960s%22%20whip%20Year%3A%221962%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref> The Liberals followed suit in November 1974<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |date=20 November 1974 |page=2553 |speaker=Reg Withers |position=[[Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Australia)|Leader of the Opposition in the Senate]] |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;db=HANSARD80;id=hansard80%2Fhansards80%2F1974-11-20%2F0004;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;query=Dataset%3Ahansards,hansards80%20Decade%3A%221970s%22%20Year%3A%221974%22%20Month%3A%2211%22%20Day%3A%2220%22;rec=1;resCount=Default}}</ref> Labor added a second deputy in August 1985, pointing out that its whipping operation would then match the Coalitions (which had a Liberal whip and deputy and a National Party whip).<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |date=22 August 1985 |page=217 |speaker=[[Susan Ryan]] |position=[[Minister for Education (Australia)|Minister for Education]] |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;db=CHAMBER;id=chamber%2Fhansards%2F1985-08-22%2F0135;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;query=Dataset%3Ahansards,hansards80%20Decade%3A%221980s%22%20Year%3A%221985%22%20Month%3A%2208%22%20Day%3A%2222%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref> Liberal added a second whip in 2009, while in opposition.<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |date=4 February 2009 |speaker=[[Nick Minchin]] |position=[[Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Australia)|Leader of the Opposition in the Senate]] |page=221 |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansards,hansards80%20Decade%3A%222000s%22%20Year%3A%222009%22%20%22deputy%20whip%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref>
The National Country Party, which as the Country Party had elected a whip in the House of Representatives since its early days, first elected a Senate whip in 1973 and a deputy whip for the House of Representatives in 1976. The latter, [[Peter Fisher (Australian politician)|Peter Fisher]] MP, was subsequently elected National Country Whip in 1980, and it does not appear another deputy was elected until 1989, when the practice became standard. As of August 2013, the party does not elect a deputy whip in the Senate.
By 1994, all three major parties in the House of Representatives had a whip and a deputy whip, but only the National Party's deputy whip did not receive an additional salary. On 12 May 1994, [[Kim Beazley]], then the Leader of the House, announced that, in conjunction with the creation of the second debating chamber, the Government Whip in the House of Representatives would become the Chief Government Whip, and his deputy would become the Government Whip. In addition, a second junior whip would be added. Beazley offered the same arrangement for the Liberal Party and to see that the Nationals' deputy received a salary.<ref name=Beazley>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=12 May 1994 |page=833 |speaker=[[Kim Beazley]] |position=[[Leader of the House (Australia)|Leader of the House]] |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;db=CHAMBER;id=chamber%2Fhansardr%2F1994-05-12%2F0105;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20Decade%3A%221990s%22%20Year%3A%221994%22%20Month%3A%2205%22%20Day%3A%2212%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref> Labor elected its whip that day, and the Liberals appointed an additional whip on 2 June 1994, with the new whip responsible for business in the second chamber.<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |speaker=[[Bob Halverson]] |position=Chief Opposition Whip |date=2 June 1994 |page=1266 |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20Decade%3A%221990s%22%20Year%3A%221994%22%20bradford%20whip%20Month%3A%2206%22;rec=0;resCount=Default}}</ref>
That arrangement persists today. Labor and the Liberals each have a chief whip and two whips in the House of Representatives and a chief whip and a two deputy whips in the Senate. The Nationals have a chief whip and whip in the House and one whip in the Senate. In addition, the Greens have had a whip in the Senate since May 1995. Other parties have also had whips. When the [[Democratic Labour Party (Australia)|Democratic Labor Party]] (now the Democratic ''Labour'' Party) increased from two to four senators in July 1968, it elected a whip who served until he and the rest of the DLP senators lost their seats at the [[Australian federal election, 1974|1974 double dissolution election]]. The Australian Democrats had a whip from 1981 until 2008, when all four senators left office following their loss at the [[Australian federal election, 2007|2007 election]].
==Salary== Until 1952, whips received no salary apart from their pay as a parliamentarian.<ref>{{cite Hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=House of Representatives |date=27 August 1952 |page=619 |speaker=[[Robert Menzies]] |position=[[Prime Minister of Australia]] |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;orderBy=_fragment_number,doc_date-rev;page=0;query=Dataset%3Ahansardr,hansardr80%20%22whip%22%20%22salary%22%20Decade%3A%221950s%22%20Year%3A%221952%22;rec=1;resCount=Default}}</ref> The Government whip, however, received payment from a pool each Cabinet minister paid into.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article107236926 |title=News in Brief |work=The Peak Hill Express |location=Peak Hill, NSW |date=1 September 1905 |page=13}}</ref> The ''Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952'' provided salaries for the whips of each recognised party in both the Senate and House of Representatives.<ref>[http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Series/C1952A00002/Amendments ''Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952''] (Cth) s 10. Retrieved 15 August 2013.</ref> Although the parties began appointing deputy whips in the 1950s and 1960s, they were not provided a salary until 1973.<ref>[http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C1973A00014 ''Remuneration and Allowances Act 1973''] (Cth) s 4. Retrieved 15 August 2013.</ref>
When the Remuneration Tribunal was created, also in 1973, it was given control over parliamentary salaries and additional salaries for parliamentary officeholders, it retained salaries for the existing whips. In 1994, with the creation of the Main Committee (now the Federation Chamber), the Government effectively changed the names of the Government and Opposition Whips to "Chief Whip" and added one paid post of whip for each of the parties in the House of Representatives.<ref name=Beazley />
Currently, there are 14 paid whips in Parliament: Labor and the Liberals each have five paid whips, three in the House and two in the Senate; the Nationals have two whips in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate, and the Greens have a Senate whip. The Government and Opposition chief whips in the House of Representatives earn an additional salary equal to 26% and 23%, respectively, of their base pay as MPs.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Remuneration Tribunal |title=Determination 2013/12: Members of Parliament–Base Salary, Additional Salary for Parliamentary Office Holders, and Related Matters |url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2013L01090 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}</ref> This is roughly equal to an assistant minister (until 2015 called a parliamentary secretary) (25%).<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Remuneration Tribunal |title=Report Number 1 of 2012: Report on Ministers of State—Salaries Additional to the Basic Parliamentary Salary |url=http://www.remtribunal.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0019/12745/Report-1-of-2012.pdf}}</ref> Their counterparts in the Senate earn slightly less: 20% for the Government Chief Whip and 18% for the Opposition Chief Whip. Additional salaries for other whips range from 3% to 13% of base pay.
